title: Trapping Rain Water (Container With Most Water)
description: Given an array walls where each element walls[i] represents the height of a vertical wall at position i, find two walls that form a container (with the x-axis) holding the maximum possible water. The container cannot be tilted.

approaches.description: Check every pair of lines, calculate the area, and update max area accordingly.
steps: For each i, iterate j from i+1 to n-1.

approaches.description: Use two pointers starting from both ends and move inward, always advancing the smaller wall.

examples.explanation:
Walls at index 1 (height 9) and index 6 (height 8) form the largest container.
Width = 6 - 1 = 5, Height = min(9, 8) = 8, Area = 5 * 7 = 35
Walls at index 0 and 3: Width = 3, Height = min(2, 3) = 2, Area = 3 * 2 = 6

edge_cases.reason: Max area between first and last wall: width = 2, height = 1, area = 2

notes.greedy_pointer_movement: Always move the pointer with the shorter wall inward to try increasing the potential height.
notes.why_two_pointers_work: Each step eliminates the shorter wall, never skipping any possible maximum area.

hints: Try brute force for small inputs to understand the pattern.
Focus on how the height is limited by the shorter wall.
Notice how moving the taller wall doesn't help, but moving the shorter one might.
follow_up: Can you modify this to find the area for multiple containers?
What if walls can change over time (dynamic array)?
Can this be extended to 2D shapes for volume?
